title: Why would we want to compare the cardinality of two infinite sets in logic and set theory? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why would we want to compare the cardinality of two finite sets? The reasons are really the same. Perhaps you would want to see an concrete example of a situation where comparing the cardinality of two infinite sets reveals a significant fact. One such example was given by Georg Cantor, the father of the modern notion of cardinality, in the very first paper where he shown that there are infinite sets of different cardinality. Cantor proved that the set of Real numbers has greater cardinality than the Natural numbers, but shown that the set of Algebraic numbers has the same cardinality as the Naturals. Thus, he concluded that Transcendental number exists, a fact that was proven in great efforts only 25 years before by Joseph Liouville. to this day, Cantor proof is the only simple one known.

It is generally accepted that “infinite set” is one of “infinite things” need to be cognized in mathematics: （1）Each “infinite set” is comprised by “infinite elements”-------there will be no infinite sets without “infinite related things”; （2）Each “distinctive infinite set” is comprised by “distinctive infinite things (infinite elements) with their special nature, special existing condition, special manifestation and special relationship among each other”---------there will be no different infinite sets without “different kinds of distinctive infinite elements”; （3）Because of the recognition of “distinctive infinite elements with their quantity related ‘special nature, special existing condition, special manifestation and special relationship among each other’” in infinite sets, the “infinite sets” and “infinite elements in infinite sets” can be quantitative studied and cognized. The existence of “infinite many elements” decides the existence of “infinite sets” and the existence of “different kinds of distinctive infinite elements” decides the existences of “different infinite sets” as well as their set elements with visiable, touchable and manifestable natures for quantitative studying and cognizing.

Why would we want to climb Mt. Everest? Because its there. Why would we want to compare the cardinality of two infinite sets in logic and set theory? Because we can! No, let’s be serious now. One of the definitions of infinity is that it can be put into one-to-one correspondence with a subset of itself. Comparing the cardinality of two sets can help to identify that the set we’re working with is indeed an infinite set. I’m sure there are other reasons, but that one comes to mind quickly.
